content.text: Connect the circuit of Fig. 1.1
You should expect to spend at least 15 minutes setting up your circuit

Adjust the variable resistor until the current reading is at a maximum
Measure and record the ammeter reading \(I\) and the voltmeter reading \(V.\)

Open the switch when you have taken all your readings
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{I}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{V}\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and the \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =

where \(R\) and \(k\) are constants
Use your answer in **(d)(iii)** to determine the value of \(R\)
Give appropriate units
In this experiment you will investigate how the characteristics of a circuit vary with its resistance
Measure and record the thickness \(t\) of the metre rule
Measure and record the diameter \(d\) of cylinder A
Calculate \(w\), where \(w = d - t\)
Use modelling clay to secure cylinder A to the bench and balance the metre rule on the cylinder, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Move one end of the rule downwards
Release the rule and watch the movement
The end of the rule will move upwards and then downwards again, completing a swing as shown in Fig. 2.2
The time taken for each complete swing is \(T\)
By timing several of these complete swings, determine an accurate value for \(T\)
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(T\)
percentage uncertainty =   .........
Repeat (b) and (c) for cylinder B

Explain whether your results support the suggested relationship
It is suggested that the quantities \(T\) and \(w\) are related by the equation
where \(k\) is a constant
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
You may not need to use all of the materials provided
In this experiment you will investigate how the motion of a metre rule balanced on a cylinder depends on the diameter of the cylinder
